bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Robert P. Cooke, March 21, 1941

div1.p: Hench asks Cooke to edit his letter to Ramos, requesting that he emphasize Finlay's contribution.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Robert P. Cooke, March 21, 1941
div1.opener:
else
for answer
Y F.
March 21, 1941
Dr. Robert P. Cooke
Lexington-Rockbridge Health Department
Lexington, Virginia
My dear Doctor Cooke:
div1.p:
I am sorry indeed to have intruded on your busy days but I felt
sure that you would be interested in my report to Doctor Ramos. Furthermore, I
know that a letter from you to Doctor Ramos will do much to interest him in the
report.

I received the letter and am taking it with me tonight. There is
one point which worries me somewhat - the last paragraph. As you may know the
Cubans have quite a campaign on to show that Reed and his colleagues were relative-
ly unimportant - they merely confirmed the work of Finlay. Finlay is their god
and their crusade in his behalf is a zealous one to say the least. They are
sympathetic with Lazear, the martyr, but aren't very excited about Reed.

Could I trouble you, therefore, to re-write your letter just as
it is in the first paragraph (I assume you have a copy) but change the short last
paragraph to read something like this:

“The probability that the site will be preserved as a fitting
memorial to the conquest of yellow fever by Finlay, and by Reed and his colleagues,
who are among the world's greatest benefactors, will I am sure, be a source of
real satisfaction and a sympathetic bond of union between our governments.”

If you can airmail such a letter, addressed to me at the Clinic,
my secretary will have it photostated and send the original and a couple photostatic
copies on to me in Florida or Havana next week. I hate to ask you to go to this
trouble but I do believe such a letter from you would be received with more grace
by Doctor Ramos.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. rec'd 3/26/41
